JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, FEBRUARY 6, 1959

63RD YEAR

Griswold To Speak at Commemoration
Is In Danger,

Ivins and no losses
the Marietta
College of Ohio
team
of Linda
Ann Ingols
and Paul Gray bested

ting 39 other colleges and
universit
ies throughout
the United
States to win the

Hopkins
University Invitational Debate
trourna.ment, held at Homewood
last Friday
and Saturday.

College, and St.

Of five
wins and one defeat

Which

had

nin

Speech
Dr. H. Bentley Glass of Johns
Hopkins warned over 200 students from 40 colleges and univer.sities attending a banquet
concluding the JHU Invitational
Debate Tournament last Saturday night that unless Americans
start getting a better understanding of the nature of modern
day science, democracy may be
in danger.
Dr. Glass based this admonition on the "bad job" being done
by the newspapers, magazines
and other communications media
in interpreting science to the lay
populace. This has resulted, he
charged, in science's
being
"hardly different to most Americans today than magic was to the
people of the Middle Ages"—
completely incomprehen.sible.
"Science is not magic button
pushing," declared the eminent
Hopkins biologist.
Sign Of Strength
"Science occupies a place of
strategic importance in our
civilization. How strong we are
militarily, economically, and socially depends to a great extent
upon just how strong we are
scientifically.
"We are now in a scientific
race with Russia, in a race in
which many believe we are falling behind. Many have stated we
are as much as five years behind
the Soviet Union.
''Every
thinking American
must therefore be concerned by
the degree to which we in democracy fail. to understand the
nature of science.
Need Enlightenment
"There is need for enlightened
direction of scientific affairs."
The leadership in scientific developinent America is presently
getting was not enlightened
enough, the Professor implied,
for he pointed out: "We spend
millions and millions for science
out of every budget; but only a
small percentage of that money
is used for basic research; most
is used on military hardware;
little to solve new problems."
Dr. Glass was particularly concerned with the size of the budget given toward biological research. "When we finally do get
a rocket up into space we may
not be ready to send up human
beings unless we devote more
(Continued on Page 2)

Yale President Demands
Educational Progress

Deans To Meet
And Admonish
Neat Guy's Crew
"We've got the names of boys
involved in the games. Dean
Shaffer and I intend to talk to
them. What will happen if they
don't heed our warning, I don't
know."
With these words Dean of
Students William K. Morrill gave
vent to what he called "the administration's view" of the recent dorm gambling problem and
in effect outlined his own intended action to the now notorious "Neat Guy" and his moneythumbing gang who control the
ring.
Speaking at last Tuesday's
Student Council meeting in
Levering Hall, Dean Morrill also
stated: "There is no administration rule saying you can't
gamble, but gambling of any sort
is not good ... it is psychologically harmful to both winners
and losers.
"It is especially bad when
gambling reaches big stakes or
keeps students awake all night
so they miss their morning
classes," he continued, adding,
"this is what we'd like to stop
... we hope they'll see the light."
Dean Morrill also reported that
effacement of dormitory lawns
would lessen due to a resolution
passed by the Dormitory Student Residence Council this week
which states that any student
found driving his car on lawns
(Continued on Page 2)

No Lack of Opportunity for Learning, Says Griswold;
Stresses Reforms of Teaching Methods
President A. Whitney Griswold of Yale University
will spealc_at annual commemoration day ceremonies of
the Johns Hopkins University Monday, February 23, at
10 a.m. in Shriver Hall.
The 52-year-old political scientist has been a leader
in the crusade for higher standards in American secondary .
education. President Griswold' has stressed reforms in
the training of teachers as a means to improve the value
of the high school diploma, and emphasized the necessity
for increased awareness of education's worth.

A. WHITNEY GRISWOLD

Initial Impact Prime
In Theatre Brady
On Sunday evening, January
18, 1959, a large and enthusiastic audience heard Mr. Leo
Brady, professor of Speech and
Drama at Catholic University,
deliver the 'second annual Amos
Taylor, Jr. Memorial Lecture in
•
the Clipper Room of Shriver
Hall.
Professor Brady's topic was:
"Theatre as Theatre." In a talk
that was both witty and informative, Professor Brady emphasized the value of viewing theatre
as theatre. In general, our enjoyment of a play will not ultimately depend on whether or not
we have been specially prepared
and formally trained in theatre,
but, rather, on the impression
which the initial impact. of the
dramatic experience makes on us
to affect our opinion of the play
and our attitude toward it. The
judgement which we make of the
play will not necessarily be dictated by formal academic "rules",
but rather, by how we feel toward the play.

What Is, Is Good
A dramatic production needs
no justification beyond its own
existence, since a play is a play
foremost, and a social criticism,
aommentarY, or psychological
study only secondly. Two "nonaesthetic attitudes" toward theatre are the scientific attitude
and the personal attitude. The
former position stresses the
necessity of having,some specialized academic training or background in theatre, or in the history of the period in which the
play takes place, or a knowledge
H. Bentley Glass presents trophy to the winners of the of the playwright's background.
kolitivakithual Johns Hopkins Debate Tournament, Marietta
Critics or teachers, who are
Paid Gray and Linda Ann Ingols.
occupied with searching for hid-

den levels of meaning in a play,
for example, tend not to be affected by the initial impact of
the dramatic experience, upon
which Professor Brady places
prime importance. It is necessary to subordinate the scientific approach to unencumbered
enjoyment of theatre as theatre,
and to openly receive the dramatic experience.
Concerning our personal attitude toward a play, Professor
Brady is opposed to extremes. He
favors an attitude toward a play
which combines attachment and
removal, lest the aesthetic value
of the play be lost to us.
Appeal To Senses
Finally, Professor Brady listed
the criteria which he believes
necessary to a play. He feels
that, in order to be effective, a
play must appeal to the senses
(through set-design). Also, a play
must arouse emotions in the
audience (pity, love, fear, etc.)
which will have to be quieted by
the end of the play. Finally, a
play must be intellectually satisfying to us by its conclusion.
Our sense of order demairls, if
not necessarily an idyllic enling,
at least a satisfactory and ploper
conclusion to the events that
have gone before; a point-ofrest which brings with it a sense
of completion.
Following Professor Erady's
lecture, members of the. Johns
Hopkins University Playshop Association presented scenes from
The Chinese Chalk Circle. This
play dates from the time of a
fourteenth century dynasty.

F.B.

Lack Respect
"There is no lack of opportunity for learning among us,"
he said. "What is lacking is respect for it—not the unctuous
respect that trails its possessors
with diplomas and titles—but an
honest respect such as we now
have for technical competence
or business success. We honor
learning, but do not believe in
it.
"We reward it with lengthy
obituaries and a wretched living
wage. Rather than submit to it
ourselves we hire substitutes;
rather than cultivate our own
brains we pick theirs. We spend
as much time and energy on
short cuts to learning and imitations of lemmings as we do
on
learning itself."
Newer, Bigger, Better
President Griswold established
a new teacher training program
at Yale to correct the
present
program in the United States,
which he claimed "is long
on
•theories and methods of teaching and short on subject
matter
to be taught, particularly
on the
basic academic subjects."
Griswold began his Yale teaching career in 1933 after
receiving
his A.B. there in 1929 and
his
Ph. D. in 1933. He has
been an
instructor in history, an assistant professor of government
and
international relations, an associate professor of political
science
and history and professor
of
history. In 1950 he was elevated
to the position of presiden
t of
Yale University.
He is the author of several
books among which are Farming
and Democracy, Far Eastern
Policy of the United States
and
Essays in Education.

JHU Press
Gets Grant
A $9,750 Ford
Foundation
grant will go to the Johns
Hopkins University Press to
"stimu.
late scholarly publication
in the
humanities
and
the
social
sciences," the Public Relation
s
Office announced today.
This is the third
consecutive
year that the Ford
Foundation
has presented a grant-in
-aid to
the Hopkins Press.
"We are extremely grateful
to
the foundation," said
Harold
Ingle, director of the press,
"for
this grant which allows us
to
expand our publication of significant books in the social sciences
and humanities."
(

— Honor
At a recent trial the Honor
Commission found a freshman Arts and Sciences student guilty of an Honor code
violation. The penalty was
failure in the course concerned and blacklisting.

--qmoiwor—

but, rather, on the impression
which the initial impact. of the
dramatic experience makes on us
to affect our opinion of the play
and our attitude toward it. The
judgement which we make of the
play will not necessarily be dictated by formal academic "rules",
but rather, by how we feel toward the play.

What Is, Is Good
A dramatic production needs
no justification beyond its own
existence, since a play is a play
foremost, and a social criticism,
aommentarY, or psychological
study only secondly. Two "nonaesthetic attitudes" toward theatre are the scientific attitude
and the personal attitude. The
former position stresses the
necessity of having,some specialized academic training or background in theatre, or in the history of the period in which the
play takes place, or a knowledge
H. Bentley Glass presents trophy to the winners of the of the playwright's background.
kolitivakithual Johns Hopkins Debate Tournament, Marietta
Critics or teachers, who are
Paid Gray and Linda Ann Ingols.
occupied with searching for hid-

den levels of meaning in a play,
for example, tend not to be affected by the initial impact of
the dramatic experience, upon
which Professor Brady places
prime importance. It is necessary to subordinate the scientific approach to unencumbered
enjoyment of theatre as theatre,
and to openly receive the dramatic experience.
Concerning our personal attitude toward a play, Professor
Brady is opposed to extremes. He
favors an attitude toward a play
which combines attachment and
removal, lest the aesthetic value
of the play be lost to us.
Appeal To Senses
Finally, Professor Brady listed
the criteria which he believes
necessary to a play. He feels
that, in order to be effective, a
play must appeal to the senses
(through set-design). Also, a play
must arouse emotions in the
audience (pity, love, fear, etc.)
which will have to be quieted by
the end of the play. Finally, a
play must be intellectually satisfying to us by its conclusion.
Our sense of order demairls, if
not necessarily an idyllic enling,
at least a satisfactory and ploper
conclusion to the events that
have gone before; a point-ofrest which brings with it a sense
of completion.
Following Professor Erady's
lecture, members of the. Johns
Hopkins University Playshop Association presented scenes from
The Chinese Chalk Circle. This
play dates from the time of a
fourteenth century dynasty.

F.B.

Lack Respect
"There is no lack of opportunity for learning among us,"
he said. "What is lacking is respect for it—not the unctuous
respect that trails its possessors
with diplomas and titles—but an
honest respect such as we now
have for technical competence
or business success. We honor
learning, but do not believe in
it.
"We reward it with lengthy
obituaries and a wretched living
wage. Rather than submit to it
ourselves we hire substitutes;
rather than cultivate our own
brains we pick theirs. We spend
as much time and energy on
short cuts to learning and imitations of lemmings as we do
on
learning itself."
Newer, Bigger, Better
President Griswold established
a new teacher training program
at Yale to correct the
present
program in the United States,
which he claimed "is long
on
•theories and methods of teaching and short on subject
matter
to be taught, particularly
on the
basic academic subjects."
Griswold began his Yale teaching career in 1933 after
receiving
his A.B. there in 1929 and
his
Ph. D. in 1933. He has
been an
instructor in history, an assistant professor of government
and
international relations, an associate professor of political
science
and history and professor
of
history. In 1950 he was elevated
to the position of presiden
t of
Yale University.
He is the author of several
books among which are Farming
and Democracy, Far Eastern
Policy of the United States
and
Essays in Education.

JHU Press
Gets Grant
A $9,750 Ford
Foundation
grant will go to the Johns
Hopkins University Press to
"stimu.
late scholarly publication
in the
humanities
and
the
social
sciences," the Public Relation
s
Office announced today.
This is the third
consecutive
year that the Ford
Foundation
has presented a grant-in
-aid to
the Hopkins Press.
"We are extremely grateful
to
the foundation," said
Harold
Ingle, director of the press,
"for
this grant which allows us
to
expand our publication of significant books in the social sciences
and humanities."
(

— Honor
At a recent trial the Honor
Commission found a freshman Arts and Sciences student guilty of an Honor code
violation. The penalty was
failure in the course concerned and blacklisting.
